review_title: Some departments are great. Zero opportunity for advancement.
pros: If you land in the right department, the team can be great. Campus is beautiful. Benefits are great, but don't pay your bills.
cons: Many departments in academic affairs are a toxic mess led by inept people with zero leadership. Departments within a college practically cannibalize each other. Union positions protect awful employees and do not reward those who excel. There is zero opportunity to move through the pay scale. The idea of professional development does not exist. Expecting someone with 10+ years of experience to start at the bottom of the payscale is a joke. I had to fight tooth and nail for 15% above base and have not seen a merit increase in the 5+ years I've been on campus. The university is bleeding qualified staff fleeing for remote options with far better pay.

job_title: Student Assistant (IT Support) in Chico, CA
pros: Student jobs are great when you can get them. I worked for Creative Media Technology / Classroom Technology Services. Basically always minimum wage, but having a student job with federal work study makes you also eligible for food stamps, which is a really good deal when you're in school. The work is simple, many jobs are educational, and the managers are generally there to support you, sometimes even more than you're there to support the work. But if you want a student job and have never had one before, the best thing to do is to start as early as possible and don't count on knowing where openings will be posted--usually they aren't. To get a student job you really just have to talk to a lot of people and find out what's available--best to start with your major first. If you'd like to be a tutor, look up tutoring skills--they're real and will be important in passing an interview. With my area specifically (IT) the interview is mostly talking about tech problems you've solved or troubleshooted, times in which you've had to make a decision quickly, times when you've solved a problem in a creative way, etc. Bonus: when you find out about the position, feel free just to ask them how to prepare for their interview specifically. People in higher education are generally really cool and willing to help.
cons: Besides minimum wage, student jobs are legally maxed at 20 hours a week, and most positions alone only offer 10 hours a week, give or take. It's designed for students getting some experience and some supplemental income, it's not designed to be something to live on.

review_title: Given the freedom to do my job
pros: I enjoyed the flexible working hours. The work culture was great and there was a feeling of teamwork among the other tutors. The goal was to provide the best service we could and extra trainings were given so each tutor could be as useful to his tutees as possible.
cons: The low pay was easily the worst part of working here. I did not feel like I was being paid commensurate with my skill level, education level, and passion for the job

review_title: CSU Chico: Where the baseline is mediocrity
job_title: Administrative Support Coordinator in Chico, CA
pros: As with any organization, there are individuals - colleagues at all levels (faculty, staff, administration) who are gems. Smart, resourceful, open-minded, kind people. The kind of people that have integrity, and know what it takes to get the job done. And do it. But know that this is the exception to the rule. I worked in an academic department, where my chair and colleagues were great. I worked in various other non-academic departments where I didn't agree with the mission of the department, but I found enough about the work challenging and fulfilling enough to be engaged. Then there are departments where the leadership and culture is toxic...
cons:
This is the thing about the work culture at Chico State: the toxic culture runs deep. In certain departments, with certain people, if you're smart and competent, you will be pushed down. My sense is that certain supervisors view smart, competent subordinates as threatening, and will use controlling, bullying tactics to ensure that you know your place. And if you think that going to HR is an available recourse, just as with private companies, HR exists to protect the institution - in this case, the university. When I experienced a clear case of bullying, I filed an informal complaint that led to my meeting with the second highest administrator at the university. Far from feeling that I was heard, the administrator seemed impotent and lacking in courage. I never found out how my case was resolved, but I'd bet a pretty penny it was nothing more than a slap on the wrist. The whole experience left a bitter taste in my mouth. Ever since then, I've decided to take my talents elsewhere. 

Other cons:
- Salary for support staff is staggeringly low. You start at something like 34k annually - and that's for Administrative Support Coordinator I level. For Administrative Support Assistants, the pay scale is even lower.
- The silo mentality is alive and kicking at Chico State.  Don't be surprised when other departments don't want to share resources or information with yours. (In fact, this goes so deep that colleges are expected to fund themselves, even though all colleges are part of one university. Classes will get cut, instructors will lose their jobs - all because the university won't adopt a revenue-sharing funding model. But I digress.)
- Promotions in place (aka reclassification) or raises based on performance are virtually unheard of - unless you somehow have special dispensation.  I know a number of support staffers who are killing it at their job - and have been for years - and see virtually nothing in the way of raises. (I'm excluding the paltry General Salary Increases that are mandated by the contract between staff and the university). 
- There is a deep resistance to progress at this place. I've seen time and time again departments not using industry best practices, or reasonably current software.
- Speaking of software, prepare to acquaint yourself with some of the most user-unfriendly interfaces you will ever have to pleasure to use. Between PeopleSoft and Astra, I don't know what's worse...(Oracle, which powers PeopleSoft is incredibly powerful, I won't deny this, but again, it scores a maybe a 1/10 for user-friendliness.). Oh, and the Microsoft Suite. Outlook anyone? Word? Excel I'd keep, but those other programs can disappear from the planet and we'd all be better for it.
- There is little administrative continuity here. People are always saying, "Institutional memory is like gold around here!" Yeah, that's not a good thing. That statement is representative of a failing system. The longest-serving dean has only been here for four years. The current president: under two years. The last president stepped down after an embarrassing vote of no confidence by the Academic Senate. Administrators turn over like flapjacks, and roles are constantly filled with interim appointments. In the last ten years, including interim appointments, there have been SEVEN provosts. 
- There is a culture of disdain for faculty. You see it in the staff; you see it in the administration. (Unsurprisingly you also see it in the students). Funny, given that without faculty, neither the staff nor the administration would have jobs. People at Chico State regard the students as customers, and try to please the students at all costs. When and where I went to school, we regarded our faculty as beacons of knowledge, treated faculty with respect and reverence. We took their side in disputes with the administration. We knew that our education and personal betterment rested on the service of a faculty that was treated properly by the university. Not the case here.
- People are afraid of their shadow. Good people are pushed out, egomaniacs and narcissists rule the day, and most everyone just deals with it. If you can, I'd say look elsewhere.

review_title: Great place to work as a student
pros: If you're a student looking for employment an on-campus job is the way to go. It follows your school scheduled and often times don't have to request special time off since they are closed when you don't have classes.
cons: You don't get a lot of hours to work depending on your department and the pay is somewhat low. There's also a stronger preference for work-study students.

. All you colleagues except for leading staff attend the same college as you so it is a great way to make friends
. You don't work when school is not in session. So you get to go home for spring, winter and summer breaks.
.  Working while attending college looks good on your resume.
cons:
. If you work in kitchen you smell like food rest of the day
. Working with young college students so they sometimes randomly don't show up to work which might put more work on you.

review_title: Very low pay, stressful, unfair place to work
pros: The nursing and support staff were generally well-trained and helpful.  Working with college kids was interesting and exciting at times.  Broad range of primary care from Urgent Care and very acute cases to chronic medical problems like diabetes and hypertension management.
cons:
Even with 20+ years experience I was started at the very bottom of the pay scale. 
 From day one I was told that the salary never increases with time except for COL increases.  "The college is on a tight budget".

I looked forward to working at a clinic with regular working hours with lunch time off and regular breaks.  Unfortunately I was not given breaks as the time was needed to do admin and/or complete notes.  I was expected to stay at the clinic during lunch and be available for meetings, work on notes, admin, etc.

Appointment times were extremely short, and the physician is expected to fill out all meds, allergies, past medical history, family history, etc., complete an exam, and progress as well as well as Clean / re=stock our own rooms during the appointment slot.  Most appointments were 15 minutes and so working hours were usually 10-11 hours per day.  No overtime.  No Comp time.

Very clicky work environment, double standards.  The upstairs physicians/PAs had very different work requirements from the downstairs staff.   No time off during the active school days, even for very special occasions.

I was told that mental health services were provided for by the counseling center as well as a psychiatrist but from day 1 I was told the counseling center and psychiatrist appointments were full and that I would need to help out by seeing mental health visits.  I was not offered any training but was expected to do so on my own.  Once patient's were seen there were very few and extremely limited referral options, including suicidal, psychotic,. bipolar, schizophrenic patients.  It was an extremely dangerous situation as a physician.

Working with many mid-level providers who are not well trained or supervised creates very dangerous medical situations that fall on the physician to clean up.  Many "bad" cases.

condescending and intimidating senior medical staff and administration, forced comradery.  They will put on a good front until you have signed the contract.

pros: Benefits are great; including a possible tuition waiver.
cons: It is hard to advance. Your experience depends on who your supervisor is. Pay is not good, although benefits can make up for it.

review_title: Great place to work as a student!
pros: When employed as a student employee, the departments will work around your schedule and give you up to 20 hours/week (depending on the dept). You get great experience that looks good on your resume and great hours (no weekends).
cons: The pay isn't great as a student employee, but high wages are hard to find anywhere in Chico.

pros: I was able to really grow in my experience working with clients within the community. It was great practice and a preview for entering the workforce after College. Having group and client meetings weekly, along with strict deadlines helped to achieve client goals.
cons: This internship it time consuming, and although you receive school credit, it is unpaid.

review_title: ITSS is a good place to start as a student employee

pros: Wonderful town, beautiful campus, and great students. The CSU system, in general, offers many opportunities for a good educational experience.

review_title: Great people, but no room to grow
